RULING APRIL 10
Unabsolved Failure will Prevent
Graduation. Only Two Marks
Below 7 Permitted
Under the new regulation prescribed by the Board of Collegiate
Studies no student may graduate
with an unabsolved failure (due to
the dropping of a course) against
him. This is the spirit of the ruling drawn up on April 10, which
also forbids a candidate for graduation to present for his degree
more than two subjects in which
his mark was below-seven.
The regulations as adopted are
as follows:
"If for any reason a student
does not repeat or otherwise - absolve a course in which he has
failed, he may, with the- consent of
his adviser, substitute another
course of equal value, IAA in every
such case he -will be required as a
penalty for leaving a course uncompleted, to take an additional
course which will not be credited
toward the 125 points'required for
graduation.
"No student may count for graduation more than two courses in
which his grade for the year is below 7.
"A student whose average mark
in Mathematics I is below 7 will
not be permitted to take Mathematics II.
"A student transferring from
one undergraduate school to another, and haying a failure in the
former, must, in addition to the
regular requirements for a degree
in the school which he is entering,
make up the failure or offer an additional equivalent course."
Dr. Latane, when questioned
about the purpose of the new regulations, declared: -- "We do not like to give a degree to a man who has had poor
marks throughout."
Thus under the rules just adopted the general marks of graduates
will be of a much higher calibre
than formerly. Men will, for example, be prevented from dropping courses when they- become a
little "stiff."

Unabsolved Failure will Prevent
Graduation. Only Two Marks
Below 7 Permitted
Under the new regulation prescribed by the Board of Collegiate
Studies no student may graduate
with an unabsolved failure (due to
the dropping of a course) against
him. This is the spirit of the ruling drawn up on April 10, which
also forbids a candidate for graduation to present for his degree
more than two subjects in which
his mark was below-seven.
The regulations as adopted are
as follows:
"If for any reason a student
does not repeat or otherwise - absolve a course in which he has
failed, he may, with the- consent of
his adviser, substitute another
course of equal value, IAA in every
such case he -will be required as a
penalty for leaving a course uncompleted, to take an additional
course which will not be credited
toward the 125 points'required for
graduation.
"No student may count for graduation more than two courses in
which his grade for the year is below 7.
"A student whose average mark
in Mathematics I is below 7 will
not be permitted to take Mathematics II.
"A student transferring from
one undergraduate school to another, and haying a failure in the
former, must, in addition to the
regular requirements for a degree
in the school which he is entering,
make up the failure or offer an additional equivalent course."
Dr. Latane, when questioned
about the purpose of the new regulations, declared: -- "We do not like to give a degree to a man who has had poor
marks throughout."
Thus under the rules just adopted the general marks of graduates
will be of a much higher calibre
than formerly. Men will, for example, be prevented from dropping courses when they- become a
little "stiff."
